title: Slow the rise to 12pc super, says Keating economist
text:
The annual incremental increases should be reduced to 25 basis points from 2021 and the change phased in until around 2030, he said.

That would be slower than the scheduled 50 basis point annual rise due between 2021 and 2025.

Prime Minister Scott Morrison has come under pressure from Liberal backbenchers to halt the Labor-legislated super guarantee increase and the policy is due to be considered by the retirement income review chaired by former Treasury official Mike Callaghan.

Labor, the powerful $2.7 trillion superannuation industry and trade unions, have warned the review must not be a stalking horse to undermine lifting the super guarantee and people's retirement incomes.

Mr Morrison and Josh Frydenberg have said there are no plans to change the guarantee, with the Treasurer saying on Monday the policy "has not changed".

Dr FitzGerald said he still strongly supported ultimately raising the rate to 12 per cent to lift people's living standards in retirement and to avoid over-reliance on the age pension.

Opposition Leader Anthony Albanese on Monday rejected suggestions for the guarantee to be delayed or stopped and accused the government of undermining people's retirement incomes.

"They're obsessed with undermining industry super," Mr Albanese said. "It is critical the legislated change be continued."

Advertisement

Labor Prime Minister Paul Keating was a major architect of compulsory super, introduced in 1992, and has long advocated for the super guarantee to rise. Dr FitzGerald was a senior Treasury official leading the government's national savings review at the time.

Karen Chester, who was a junior Treasury economist on Dr FitzGerald's savings review in 1993, recommended in her Productivity Commission report last year that the government instigate an independent inquiry into the retirement income system before any possible increase in the super guarantee.

Dr FitzGerald said Ms Chester's call for an inquiry "makes a lot of sense" because the retirement system hadn't had a comprehensive government review since his national savings report for Mr Keating 26 years ago.

Dr FitzGerald's view on super has evolved since January, when he told the Financial Review that he supported the scheduled rise in the super guarantee to 12 per cent.

Grattan Institute research suggests the super guarantee increase will remove $20 billion from the pockets of workers each year.

Dr FitzGerald said he did not agree with all of the Grattan analysis.

The government was “morally” obliged to improve the superannuation system ahead of a legislated increase in the super guarantee to 12 per cent, Assistant Minister for Superannuation Jane Hume said in June.
description: The economist who led Paul Keating's inquiry into compulsory superannuation said the Morrison government should slow the increase in the super guarantee to 12 per cent to boost the sluggish economy.
